unnormalised: What are some major public health challenges in India?
normalised: What are some major public health challenges in India?

unnormalised: India faces several significant public health challenges. One major area of concern is communicable diseases. Diseases like TB, malaria, and dengue continue to be prevalent, particularly in densely populated areas and regions with poor sanitation. For instance, in 2023, there were over 2.5 million cases of TB reported, according to MoHFW data. Addressing these requires improved disease surveillance, timely diagnosis, and effective treatment strategies. The implementation of the National Health Mission is crucial for controlling these diseases.
normalised: India faces several significant public health challenges. One major area of concern is communicable diseases. Diseases like T-B, malaria, and dengue continue to be prevalent, particularly in densely populated areas and regions with poor sanitation. For instance, in two thousand and twenty three, there were over two point five million cases of T-B reported, according to M-o-H-F-W data. Addressing these requires improved disease surveillance, timely diagnosis, and effective treatment strategies. The implementation of the National Health Mission is crucial for controlling these diseases.

unnormalised: Another pressing issue is the increasing burden of non-communicable diseases (NCDs). Conditions like diabetes, heart disease, and cancer are on the rise due to factors such as changing lifestyles, dietary habits, and aging populations. According to a WHO report, NCDs account for approximately 60% of deaths in India. Early detection through regular health check-ups, promoting healthier lifestyles, and providing affordable treatment options are vital. Programs like the National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke (NPCDCS) aim to address this.
normalised: Another pressing issue is the increasing burden of non-communicable diseases (N-C-Ds). Conditions like diabetes, heart disease, and cancer are on the rise due to factors such as changing lifestyles, dietary habits, and aging populations. According to a W-H-O report, N-C-Ds account for approximately sixty percent of deaths in India. Early detection through regular health check-ups, promoting healthier lifestyles, and providing affordable treatment options are vital. Programs like the National Programme for Prevention and Control of Cancer, Diabetes, Cardiovascular Diseases and Stroke (N-P-C-D-C-S) aim to address this.

unnormalised: Maternal and child health also remains a challenge. While there has been progress in reducing infant and maternal mortality rates, disparities persist across different states and socio-economic groups. Ensuring access to quality antenatal care, safe delivery practices, and post-natal care is essential. Schemes like Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) aim to incentivize institutional deliveries and improve maternal health outcomes. Moreover, addressing malnutrition in children under 5 yrs old is critically important.
